You are helping analyze a persuasion conversation with intentions. Predict whether the persuadee will make a donation on the spot at the end of this conversation. Provide your answer in the format 'DONATION: YES/NO'

Conversation:
Persuader: Hello how do you feel about the Save the Children charity? [Initiate conversation and gauge opinion on Save the Children charity]
Persuadee: I think it's a scam [Express skepticism and negative opinion about the charity]
Persuader: Oh no not at all they do tons of good  is an international non-governmental organization that promotes children's rights, provides relief and helps support children in developing countries. [Defend the charity and provide information about its mission]
Persuadee: I don't believe it. [Express disbelief in the charity's legitimacy]
Persuadee: There is no way to prove where all those funds go. [Question the transparency of the charity's fund allocation]
Persuadee: Plus there are starving children right here in america [Highlight local issues to counter the charity's focus]
Persuader: This is a great organization and I am sure that they would not be allowed to continue the way they do if the money was not going where it is suppose to and every penny being accounted for. [Reaffirm trust in the charity's accountability and transparency]
Persuader: They do so much good in the world yes there are hungry kids here but millions of Syrian children have grown up facing the daily threat of violence. [Emphasize the charity's global impact and the severity of issues it addresses]
Persuader: In the first two months of 2018 alone, 1,000 children were reportedly killed or injured in intensifying violence. [Provide specific data to support the charity's impact]
Persuadee: That is all your opinion. [Dismiss the provided information as opinion]
Persuadee: You have no facts to back that up. [Challenge the credibility of the information provided]
Persuader: Yes part of the money does go to pay for things like advertising and all that but over 88% of the donations they recieve are sent where they are needed and that includes in the United States believe it or not. [Clarify the allocation of donations and provide supporting data]
Persuader: This is according to a website that breaks down info on different charities [Cite a source to back up the information provided]
Persuadee: Like I said those are opinions. [Reiterate that the information provided is opinion-based]
Persuadee: There are no facts that prove that to be true. [Assert the lack of factual evidence supporting the charity's claims]
Persuadee: There are no laws that stop them from lying to people either. [Claim that there are no regulations preventing the charity from being dishonest]
Persuadee: I have never meet anyone who has been aided by that organization. [Express personal lack of evidence of the charity's impact]
Persuadee: Infomercials don't impress me. [Discredit the charity's promotional efforts]
Persuader: How about the fact that they have been around for over 100 years scams do not stay around that long [Argue the charity's long-standing presence as evidence of its legitimacy]
Persuadee: Yes they do. [Disagree with the argument presented]
Persuadee: Have you ever heard of evangelism? [Draw a parallel with evangelism to question the charity's legitimacy]
Persuadee: Again, you're only giving me an opinion. [Reiterate that the information provided is opinion-based]
Persuadee: I just can't see any good being done. [Express inability to see the charity's positive impact]
Persuader: What about the after school programs they have right here in the US or the head start programs that they offer in many rural areas? [Provide examples of the charity's local programs]
Persuader: Just because it is not happening somewhere that you see everyday does not mean that it does not exsist. [Argue that lack of personal observation does not negate the charity's existence]
Persuader: They actually fund the head start that my child will be going to till fall. [Share personal experience with the charity's programs]
Persuader: Would you be willing to atleast donate some of what you are getting paid for this study? [Request a donation from the conversation partner]
Persuader: Right now save the children has a partnership that will double any donation made so any little bit would help [Highlight a matching donation opportunity to encourage contribution]<|eot_id|>

You are helping analyze a persuasion conversation with intentions. Predict whether the persuadee will make a donation on the spot at the end of this conversation. Provide your answer in the format 'DONATION: YES/NO'

Conversation:
Persuader: Hello! How are you doing today? [Greeting and initiating conversation]
Persuadee: I'm doing very well thank you! [Responding positively to greeting]
Persuadee: How is your day going so far? [Inquiring about the other person's well-being]
Persuader: I am doing well. [Responding to inquiry about well-being]
Persuader: My day has been busy visiting different places to speak about the charity I support. [Providing information about their day and charity work]
Persuader: Have you heard of Save the Children? [Introducing the charity "Save the Children"]
Persuadee: It sounds familiar to me, could you tell me more about it? [Expressing familiarity and requesting more information]
Persuader: Helping children in countries that are very war torn or in some form of conflict is what we help in. [Explaining the charity's mission]
Persuader: Everyday 16,000 children die before their 5th birthday, 1 out of 80 flee the country and risk everything, and 1 out of 6 kids aren't enrolled in a school or getting education that they need [Providing statistics to emphasize the charity's importance]
Persuadee: The charity sounds like it is doing some good work in an area that badly needs it. [Acknowledging the charity's good work]
Persuadee: Children should be our top priority all across the world. [Expressing a belief in the importance of children's welfare]
Persuadee: How can someone get involved and help out with this charity? [Inquiring about ways to get involved with the charity]
Persuader: Oh there are quiet a few ways. [Indicating there are multiple ways to help]
Persuader: For roughly a dollar a day you can sponsor a child, you can choose a gift to spend to a child through our catalog, you could start a fundraiser, or you can just simply donate. [Listing specific ways to support the charity]
Persuader: With that, keep in mind if you ever decide to make a monetary donation, 86% goes directly to the children, 9% fundraising, and 5% management and general. [Providing details about the allocation of donations]
Persuader: Just so you can have an idea that we use 9 out of 10 dollars directly on the children. [Reinforcing the efficient use of donations]
Persuadee: I do believe I would like to donate some money to the Save the Children charity. [Expressing a desire to donate]
Persuadee: Could I pledge $1/day to start with? [Specifying the amount they wish to donate]
Persuader: absolutely thank you so much!! [Expressing gratitude for the donation]
Persuadee: I like to donate money and time to charities that help children so I also want to thank you for educating me on this charity! [Expressing appreciation for the information and their own commitment to helping children]
Persuader: Absolutely. [Affirming the previous statement]
Persuader: I love getting the word out there on this charity. [Expressing passion for spreading awareness about the charity]<|eot_id|>

Persuadee: No, I haven't heard of Save the Children. [Indicating lack of familiarity with Save the Children]

Conversation:
Persuader: Hello [Greeting the other person.]
Persuadee: Hi. [Responding to the greeting.]
Persuader: Are you willing to donate to Save the Children? [Inquiring about willingness to donate.]
Persuadee: Yes. [Expressing willingness to donate.]
Persuadee: I would very much like to donate. [Reaffirming the intention to donate.]
Persuader: how much are you willing to donate? [Asking for the amount of donation.]
Persuadee: Well, I don't have much money right now. [Explaining financial limitations.]
Persuadee: All I can afford is $5.00. [Stating the amount they can afford to donate.]
Persuader: I think that is an excellent amount and would benefit Save the Children. [Validating the donation amount and encouraging the donor.]
Persuader: For example,millions of Syrian children have grown up facing the daily threat of violence. [Providing context about the cause.]
Persuader: In the first two months of 2018 alone, 1,000 children were reportedly killed or injured in intensifying violence. [Highlighting the urgency and severity of the situation.]
Persuader: Your donation will make an impact to better childrens' live around the world. [Emphasizing the impact of the donation.]
Persuadee: That's so horrible. [Expressing empathy and concern.]
Persuadee: I wish I could give more. [Expressing a desire to contribute more.]
Persuadee: I sponsor a poor child in India every month for $40. [Sharing personal involvement in charitable activities.]
Persuadee: I wish I could help all the children in the world. [Expressing a broader wish to help.]
Persuader: I would like to personally thank you for that. [Expressing gratitude for the donor's contributions.]
Persuader: It is very thoughtful to donate to causes that benefit disadvantaged children. [Commending the donor's thoughtfulness.]
Persuader: Your donation means a lot to that child in India [Reiterating the importance of the donor's contributions.]
Persuadee: It is the least I can do for him. [Minimizing their own contributions.]
Persuadee: Most people take for granted what they have in their lives, while there are so many thousands who do not even have the basic necessities. [Reflecting on societal disparities.]
Persuadee: Imagine not have clean water to drink. [Highlighting a basic necessity that is often taken for granted.]
Persuader: I cannot even begin to imagine that and clean water should be a basic right to every child on this planet. [Agreeing and emphasizing the importance of clean water.]
Persuadee: I agree. [Agreeing with the previous statement.]
Persuadee: There is so much wasted in the world. [Commenting on global wastefulness.]
Persuadee: I know it is possible for everyone to have enough food and water. [Expressing belief in the possibility of global sufficiency.]
Persuadee: If only the governments and politicians of the world would stop fighting and actually work toward that goal. [Criticizing political inaction and conflict.]
Persuader: Yes I agree. [Agreeing with the criticism.]<|eot_id|>

Conversation:
Persuader: Hello. [Greeting]
Persuadee: Hello! [Greeting]
Persuader: I am supposed to ask you if you care about people being killed in Syria and things like that, I don't want to cause you any emotional discomfort by talking about suffering people. [Expressing concern about causing discomfort]
Persuader: Is that okay? [Seeking permission to discuss a sensitive topic]
Persuader: To talk about suffering people and children for a minute? [Clarifying the request to discuss suffering people and children]
Persuadee: I will have no discomfort discussing suffering people. [Reassuring that discussing suffering people is acceptable]
Persuader: I think the refugee crisis is crazy, I am not sure what I would do if I was raising my kids in Syria. [Expressing personal opinion on the refugee crisis]
Persuader: If anyone could have fun in those spots it's kids though. [Attempting to find a positive aspect in a dire situation]
Persuadee: I feel really torn about the crisis. [Expressing conflicted feelings about the crisis]
Persuadee: I don't think the weight of that burden should fall on the rest of the worlds shoulders. [Stating a belief about the responsibility of the global community]
Persuadee: At the same time as a parent I would want the best possible future for my children and I know fiercly that I would do everything in my power to make sure they were in a safe place. [Relating personal parental instincts to the situation]
Persuader: I actually didn't think of it like that. [Expressing a new perspective gained from the conversation]
Persuader: I am a parent too, it feels so foreign what they are going through. [Relating personal experience as a parent to the situation]
Persuader: This whole chat thing is supposed to get me to get you to donate to Save the Children, but now I think they got me to do it instead! [Revealing the purpose of the conversation (to solicit donations)]
Persuader: I don't know if that's really okay to do though. [Expressing uncertainty about the appropriateness of soliciting donations]
Persuadee: I always wonder how much of donations actually go where ear marked. [Expressing skepticism about the allocation of donations]
Persuadee: I see on the local level how much of donations stay local and what gets spent on things I would call "stupid". [Providing an example of local donation mismanagement]
Persuadee: I am always worried if I donate it will just go to some higer up that is living the high life. [Expressing concern about potential misuse of donations]
Persuadee: Sorry Im getting off topic. [Apologizing for deviating from the main topic]
Persuader: No, that's relevant. [Validating the relevance of the concern]
Persuader: Really relevant. [Reiterating the relevance of the concern]
Persuader: It's really easy to get cynical about life and if people really benefit from any of this. [Expressing a cynical view on the effectiveness of donations]
Persuader: I usually donate in hopes I can at least feel like I did my part. [Explaining personal motivation for donating]
Persuader: If I donated and some corrupt person took it, that's the worst karma and even worst scandal imaginable. [Expressing concern about the potential misuse of donations]
Persuader: The people who donate and people who are worrying about that are the same people. [Drawing a connection between donors and their concerns]
Persuader: You're not a horrible person it sounds like, just worried if what you do even matters. [Reassuring the other person about their intentions]
Persuadee: With that all said I do feel like any orginazation that aims to help the children I am more inclined to donate to them than most. [Expressing a preference for donating to organizations that help children]<|eot_id|>
